page.title: 02LANDSCAPE
page.content: The Forest of Dean (Dean meaning 'wooded valley') is a place of contrasts; a beautiful area in general but it also has some ugliness. It was and is a working forest and many scars of former industries have been left. From the roadside broadleaf trees remain but in far fewer numbers than a century ago. Further into the forest, conifers have taken their place, densely covering the ground so that little else grows. Bracken (or fern) grows everywhere covering, in the summer months, rubbish left in the woodland and sheep roam at will, adding to the forest's pleasantness but causing danger and unsightliness to roads and footpaths. The area has always experienced hard times, no less true today with the highest unemployment rate in the County.
